description:
Special Information Session: How to Win Stakeholders & Influence Decisions

Hosted by Dr. Leslie Jensen-Inman and Jared Spool
Tuesday, September 13, at 2:30pm-3:30pm ET (18.30-19.30 GMT)
RSVP: https://info.winstakeholders.com/signup

We created our How to Win Stakeholders & Influence Decisions program to get you past your challenges with winning difficult stakeholder buy-in. Dr. Leslie Jensen-Inman and Jared Spool have mapped out solid strategies and techniques to win over your hardest-to-convince stakeholders and focus your organization on becoming more customer and user-focused.

At this special information session, Jared and Leslie will ask you about your biggest stakeholder challenges. They'll walk through the ways you can build better connections between the values of your stakeholders and the needs of your users. They’ll discuss how our 16-week program could give you the specific coaching and mentorship you need.

RSVP for our Special Information Session.

Can’t make the session, but want to find out if the How to Win Stakeholders & Influence Decisions program is right for the challenges you're facing? Get on a Clarity Call with Summer or Leslie.
summary: Special Information Session:  How to Win Stakeholders & Influence Decisions

description:
Few things are more awkward than when a product manager, developer, or stakeholder shows up with their (not very good) design idea. Do you tell them how bad it is? Do you simply tell them this is your job, and you’ll take it from here (knowing you’ll shove it in a drawer, never to give it another thought)?

It’s easy to see this situation as something that isn’t helping you do your job. That might be the wrong way to view the big picture. You’ve uncovered evidence that your counterpart is thinking about users and what they need. So how might we redirect their energy to a better design?

In this live session, Jared Spool will explore alternatives to pushing away the design ideas from well-meaning (often uninformed) stakeholders. You’ll discover how to use their desire to move a design forward in a way that increases their appreciation of the work you and your team bring.

Come to this session to explore how you’ll…

… Grow your stakeholder’s appreciation of how much thought and effort goes into intelligent design work.

… Increase the value of good design in your organization by making your design process more transparent.

… Reduce stress and increase cross-team collaboration when you create new opportunities for collecting ideas that aren’t distracting to your work.

______________________________________

description:
Hiring a new member who can’t do the work will harm your UX team. The second most harmful thing is when your hiring process scares highly-qualified candidates away, often before they even apply. You may not realize your hiring process is causing both of these things to happen every time you bring someone on.

Hiring is essential to a UX team’s success. Hiring a highly-qualified team member will grow your team’s capabilities and increase how your organization values design. Hiring poorly-qualified candidates will create months of stress and spread dysfunction across your organization.

In this live discussion, Jared Spool will explore common hiring mistakes that UX teams often make. You’ll discover approaches to hiring that will significantly improve the contributions of your future team members.

Come to this session to explore how you’ll…

… Attract highly-qualified applicants from the start, reducing the time it takes to get to an offer for someone great.

… Remove unnecessary steps in the hiring process that turn off the best candidates because they can go with a more hassle-free position.

… Turn hiring from an exhausting process nobody likes into a set of activities that energizes the team about all the new value you’ll bring to your organization.

______________________________________

description:
In every UX leader's career, there comes the point when influence becomes essential to success. There will be a stakeholder who needs convincing. Developers who need to change what they’re doing. Executives you’ll need to support a critical initiative.

Influence isn’t something you’re born with. It’s a set of skills you can learn. With these newly acquired skills, you can communicate your position so others get as excited as you about the changes you’d like to see.

Mastering these essential communication skills will open doors to more advanced levels of leadership. Objections that currently hold you back will become voices of support. A little expertise and practice in these new skills will take you a long way in your desire to make your organization more UX mature.

Join Jared Spool to explore the critical communication skills used by successful UX leaders. You’ll discover the mindset changes and practical techniques for communicating why great UX will strengthen your organization.

In this session, we’ll explore how to…

… Uncover the priorities of key stakeholders so that you can position your ideas as a way they’ll attain their critical objectives.

… Overcome mental roadblocks you’ve put in place that accidentally prevent you from genuinely collaborating with team members.

… Identify the common ground that turns the most contentious discussions into forward-moving initiatives.

______________________________________

description:
Every UX leader we know wants it, you want it too. 

You want to be brought into the decision-making process sooner. You want to have a say in the critical decisions affecting your users’ experiences.

You want your UX experience to factor in what a new feature or product should do (and what it won’t do). You want a say in the design priorities and in how long the team will have before they need to deliver.

You want to influence the time allowed for research, what can be changed, and how many designers and researchers will be on the project full-time. You want UX input into the most critical decisions that affect the UX.

Join Jared Spool to uncover how UX leaders have successfully gained strategic influence in their organizations. You’ll discover their enormous progress when they change their approach to participating in these critical discussions.

In this session, we’ll explore…

… Where decisions are made and how you’ll become part of those discussions to ensure stakeholders consider a UX perspective.

… How successful UX leaders have won over the decision makers by becoming their official go-to source for reducing significant risk.

… Which changes to your UX process you’ll need to become more influential in your organization.

description:
Be a catalyst for change through personal improvement.

You want your organization to change. You want to deliver better-designed products and services. You can lead that change.

Yet, organizations don’t change. People do. You need the product managers, developers, and key stakeholders to change. To become better at delivering great user experiences.

As a UX leader, you can take advantage of the superpowers that come from inspiration, coaching, and mentoring. 

Join Jared Spool in a live discussion where you’ll explore how great UX leaders have motivated significant organizational changes by nurturing individual relationships with their stakeholders and peers.

You’ll discover how to…

… Create a vision that inspires key product managers, developers, and other crucial individuals to work towards delivering better UX.

… Shift your peers and stakeholders to prioritize better UX through a structured coaching process.

… Build confidence and understanding across your organization with a comprehensive mentorship approach.

description:
Generate enthusiasm for delivering great UX without lecturing about UX.

What if you could generate excitement about delivering great user experiences without having to explain what UX is? 

Imagine this… you’re talking with your development and product partners about UX outcomes and they understand the value in starting with the end-in-mind. Not only do they understand, they are excited about what will happen in your users’ and customers’ lives because you’ve delivered a great UX — together.  

Join this discussion with Jared Spool to uncover the proven secrets behind sparking enthusiasm for delivering great UX. You’ll discover how an outcome-driven approach is a game changer for UX leaders like yourself.

You’ll explore how to…

… Identify the outcomes that best spark excitement amongst the developers, product managers, and stakeholders you work with every day.

… Scope your outcomes to push your team to take on challenges they’ve resisted in the past.

… Show what it means to be ready-to-ship through the lens of great user experiences.

description:
Gain influence in your organization by recruiting a powerful sponsor.

When you feel stuck because you’re getting solid resistance for your work, you need an Internal Champion. An Internal Champion is an influential person within your organization who wants to help you succeed. They reduce the friction on your most crucial UX initiatives.

The thing about Internal Champions is that you have to win them over. (And you have to win them over big.)

To win them over, you demonstrate that great UX is the best way to help them accomplish their goals. It’s the hidden key to success. That when you improve the user experience, you improve business goals that are important to your new Internal Champions. Business goals that even your toughest stakeholders will appreciate and rally behind. 

This week, join Dr. Leslie Jensen-Inman as she discusses how to attract a heavyweight Internal Champion to your cause. You’ll explore…

…The tricks to identifying which executive or senior leader has the right influence and role power to give you the support you need.

…The strategies for finding out what they need to attract them as champions. Something you’ll do that helps them succeed at their objectives.

…The pitch for showing that poor UX makes their life more difficult, which is why you need their help.

_____________________________

description:
Lead your organization to set goals and progress based on UX improvements.

As a UX leader, you’re here to change things. In particular, you’re here to improve the experience your users and customers have with your products and services.

We measure change by tracking key UX metrics. Identifying the right UX metrics is essential for getting stakeholders to see the importance of improving the users’ experience. Yet, many UX leaders treat their metrics as an afterthought. 

How do you latch onto the right UX metrics that will broaden the change you can bring to your work? Join Jared Spool as we discuss how you can establish powerful UX metrics that will showcase your team’s work.

You’ll discover how to:

… Choose your metrics from the three most persuasive categories of UX measurements so that you can show the impact of your design changes.

… Measure any aspect of UX, especially those tied to important experience outcomes.

… Move beyond averages and focus on your users’ edge cases so you can tell more powerful stories.

description:
Change the conversation from “What we build” to “Why we’re building it.”

UX outcomes have magical power. They give you a tool for aligning product managers and developers on what your current project means for your users. They communicate your users' and customers' needs for the designs you’re creating.

When you have solid UX outcomes, it changes how you talk about your users’ experiences. You’ll have an agreed-upon baseline for ensuring that the UX is at the core of your team’s product requirements. Well-defined UX outcomes demonstrate how research and design matter, pointing to real-world improvements that increase the product's value.

In this session, Jared Spool will explore the magical properties of UX outcomes and how UX leaders use them to increase the visibility of their teams’ work. You’ll discover how UX outcomes change the conversation from “what we build” to “why we’re building it.”

summary: UX Outcomes: The UX Leader’s Secret Advantage

description:
UX can speed product delivery when we know the tricks.


In many organizations, there’s a tension between delivering a product quickly and ensuring that the product has an excellent (or even good) user experience. UX leaders in those organizations hear, “We think UX is important, but we just don’t have time right now.”

UX leaders find it challenging to navigate the politics behind why product delivery gets the top priority. They need a multi-pronged approach that shows the stakeholders that UX is important while ensuring their work doesn’t obstruct critical delivery deadlines.

In this discussion, Jared Spool will explore how influential UX leaders have overcome this challenge and made UX a priority in their organizations. You’ll discover approaches to using UX that speed delivery, making it a win-win scenario across the board.

summary: Navigating the Politics of UX vs. Product Delivery

description:
Work in an environment where UX is the priority.

In many organizations, delivering a great user experience does not come naturally. UX leaders must remind, encourage, and pester their stakeholders and peers to consider users' needs in critical decisions and discussions. It always feels like a struggle to deliver the minimum of good experiences. In these organizations, great UX is not part of their culture.

It’s possible, however, to build a culture where this isn’t a daily struggle. You can make a culture where stakeholders and decision-makers are hungry for detailed user research. Products only ship when it’s clear they’ll improve users’ lives. You can build a culture of great UX in your own organization.

In this session, Jared Spool will explore how UX leaders can build a culture of great UX in their organization. You’ll discover the baby steps necessary to start your organization down a path where the needs of the user factor into every decision.

summary: Building Up an Org Culture of Great UX

description:
Your UX Outcome answers the question: If you do a great job on your product, how will you improve someone’s life? Unfortunately, this deceptively simple question turns out to be extremely difficult to answer.

The answer is essential because it drives every component of your UX strategy. If your team doesn’t understand how their work can improve someone’s life, why are they working on it? If you don’t have the outcome as a goal, how will you know when you will achieve it?

You can use UX outcomes to determine compelling and persuasive UX metrics. You can also use them to influence the product roadmap, define a research agenda, and know who to hire for your team. You need an easy way to identify your essential UX outcomes to succeed in your UX strategy.

In this discussion, Jared Spool will walk you through several techniques for leading your team to develop UX outcomes they’ll rally around. You’ll explore how to effectively facilitate a session that will break through your co-workers' desire to create solutions instead of having a deep and meaningful discussion of the problems your users encounter.

summary: Talk UX Strategy With Jared Spool

description:
Note: This session is on Tuesday due to the U.S. Memorial Day holiday.

Transform your organization with insights that make a difference.

Every big decision affects your users’ experience. What products or features should you build next? How will you tell when it’s ready to deliver? Who will be on the team that builds and delivers it? How long will the team have to work on it?

Are the people who make these big decisions — the executives and key stakeholders — are they basing their decisions on user research? For most organizations, the answer is no.

Yet, these are the very decisions that most need user research insights. So how do we infuse these decisions with the research that will produce innovative, game-changing results?

In this session, Jared Spool will explore how UX leaders have transformed their research practices to target the big decisions affecting their users. In addition, you’ll discover how to position research as a strategic tool for raising your team’s influence.

You’ll want to bring your Product leadership to this highly-informative session. They’ll see how proactive user research will make their jobs easier and their decisions substantially less risky.

description:

summary: Growing UX Beyond a UX Team of One

description:

There is a point where operationalizing UX design, research, and content becomes essential for making our teams more effective. When you hit that point, building a DesignOps effort becomes the best path forward.

Identifying the right moment becomes key to the effort’s success. If we start it too late, we slow down UX work and spread our efforts too thin across the organization. description:
Increase the flexibility and agility of your UX team.

At first glance, establishing a formal UX process seems like a good thing. However, it often can hurt your UX team’s efforts more than it helps. Establishing a process sends the message that all UX problems are solved the same way, with the same inputs producing the same outputs. Unfortunately, your process may lead to a frustrated team and mediocre UX work.

Many UX leaders find it’s better to adopt a playbook approach. Your team fits their approach to solving hard research and design problems using a mix-and-match combination of techniques, methods, and advanced skills. The results are higher quality and more innovative designs, which improve the value of your team’s contributions.

In this discussion, Jared Spool will explore how a great UX playbook is a game-changer for UX leaders, pushing their teams to see vastly improved results from their work. You’ll discover how this simple mindset change can unleash a more flexible way of tailoring UX efforts to the true problems your product teams face.

Inspire your Agile teams to up their UX game with solid UX objectives.


User stories, by themselves, don’t lead an agile team to deliver a quality user experience. Instead, the team needs solid UX goals to establish each sprint’s “definition of done” and give the team a clear picture of success.

In this session, Jared Spool will outline a strategy that highly-effective UX leaders use to focus their agile teams on delivering innovative, high-quality products and services. He’ll detail the rituals, tips, and techniques for aligning teams with practical and powerful UX goals.

description:
Brand is the inescapable collision of Marketing and UX.

Your organization’s brand represents how your customers think of you. It’s what gets customers to think of your products and services. It’s how customers choose you over your competitors.

Organizations invest in building stronger brands. What’s the best investment? It’s not in a new logo, product name, or tag line. It’s in the experiences your products and services deliver. That’s what will stand out and strengthen your brand the most.

In this session, Jared Spool will explore how UX leaders strengthen brands when they focus on delivering compelling products and services. We’ll discuss how UX teams can partner with marketing brand efforts and how a memorable, delightful experience is the best way to strengthen brands.

description:
When saying ‘no’ is a UX leader’s secret to making significant progress.

It’s a natural inclination for UX teams to say ‘yes’ to every project opportunity. After all, they want your help, and that’s not always been the case. The downside of saying ‘yes’ too much is that we start spreading ourselves too thin. That makes it hard to do quality work for anyone.
Successful UX leaders employ a well-defined UX strategy to clearly identify which projects their teams say ‘yes’ to and which ones they politely decline. They don’t abandon those other teams. Instead, they give them support to become self-reliant. This, in turn, boosts the organization’s overall UX maturity — a win-win for all.

description:
Difficult hiring is made worse when your process unwittingly pushes away your most ideal candidates.

Hiring new UX team members has never been more challenging. The most-qualified candidates get to pick their next team (and it may not be yours). Meanwhile, hiring managers are flooded with applicants who don’t have the necessary skills, experience, and knowledge to succeed in the new position.

This problem is made worse when the team, often unknowingly, pushes ideal candidates away. Candidates believe the team doesn’t have their act together. Or they conclude the job is not right for them, when it clearly is a great match. These faux pas are easy to make, and it’s likely the team never finds out. Hiring is hard.

In this session, Jared Spool explores unintentional gaffes your team could be making and what you can do about them. You’ll learn how successful UX leaders speed their hiring process, and hone right in on ideal candidates. If you’re expanding your team in the next few months, don’t miss this discussion._________________________________________________

description:
Gain powerful leadership skills that work when work gets political.

When your organizations are political, our normally challenging work becomes even more difficult. It would be great if you could just wish the politics away and ask everyone to get on the same page. Unfortunately, that’s not a wish that’ll ever come true.

Successful UX leaders learn to go beyond “navigating” politics. They learn to use it to their advantage. In this session, Jared Spool will break down why organizations get political and what we can do when it happens. You’ll learn the secrets of exceptional UX leaders, who turn to servant leadership to get high-level support and sponsorship to produce results.

description:
Avoiding generic one-size-fits-all solutions.

When thinking about users, it’s easy to gravitate to roles. The users of an education service might be students, teachers, and parents. A healthcare product might serve patients, doctors, and nurses. It’s easy to think this way, but it’s also remarkably unhelpful.

The problem with these generic role-based personas is they imply that everyone in a given role approaches the product the same way. That all teachers work the same. That all doctors need the same capabilities. It pushes us into a one-solution-fits-all approach that only gets us into trouble.

In this session, we’ll discuss how personas work best when we start by understanding what our users do with our products and services. Jared Spool will lead a discussion into the subtlety and nuance we need to craft truly effective designs that meet the needs of users and customers.

description:
Live Job Ad Critique and Rewrite with Jared Spool

Lead by Jared Spool
October 14, 2021, 2pm ET (18.00 GMT)

Hiring new UX professionals is hard work. Part of what makes it hard is attracting the right applicants. When we get highly-qualified applicants, the hiring job goes much easier.

Yet, too many teams don’t realize how much their job advertisements are preventing those highly-qualified applicants from actually applying. In many cases, the way the ad is written pushes applicants away, leaving teams only to have less-qualified applicants flooding their candidate pool. Less-qualified applicants make hiring take longer and risk ending up with someone who isn’t right for the job.

That’s why Jared is hosting our first Live Critique and Rewrite session. During this special live session, he'll go over exactly what you need to include in (and maybe even more importantly what to leave out of) your job ad so you can save time and attract highly-qualified applicants.

Join us on October 14 as Jared walks you through the common traps that hiring teams fall into, which drive off the exact candidates they’re trying to attract. He’ll work with the hiring manager who wrote the ads, to craft a more persuasive, compelling advertisement that will attract exactly the right candidate the team is seeking.

If you're not ready for a live critique, you can sign up to just observe the session. You'll learn a whole bunch just by watching ads get critiqued and rewritten.

____________________________________

Register to Attend the Session

ONE SPOT LEFT
Register to have your current job advertisement improved. We’ll only have time to critique 3 ads. The first three hiring managers to sign up for $499 will get a live critique and a free 30-day post on our UX Centered Careers job board (a $300 value). 

LIMITED SPOTS AVAILABLE 
Register to observe the critiques and learn how to create a great job ad yourself. It’s only $99 to join. The spots to observe are limited too, so don’t miss out. These will sell out quickly.

We hope you’ll join us on October 14, 2021, 2pm ET (18.00 GMT) for this new session focused on helping you hire the UX team members your organization needs.

Once you’ve registered, we will send you the session meeting location and information.

description:
Hiring great team members is hard. Why make it harder?

There’s a high chance your most recent job advertisement isn’t doing as well as you wanted it to do. Instead of attracting highly-qualified applicants, it’s pushing them away. Instead of clearly communicating the skills you require for the position, it’s attracting under-qualified applicants by the dozens. Or nobody at all.

Many hiring managers make the mistake of copying someone else’s job ad. This makes it impossible for the best-qualified candidates to find any reason to apply. And, many hiring managers don’t even realize they’ve done this.

If you’re not getting the candidates you’d like to see into your hiring process, you may need to rework your job ad. In this session, Jared will share what makes compelling job ads work. He’ll explore how the most effective ads make it irresistible for highly-qualified applicants to apply.

description:
(Note: This session will be on a Tuesday due to the U.S. Labor Day holiday.)

Conduct better research by building an effective participant recruitment process.

Effective user research requires us to have qualified participants in our research sessions. This makes participant recruitment a critical part of any user research effort.

Yet, too many teams wait until the weeks (or even days) before their scheduled sessions to think about how they’ll find the participants they’ll need. They try to recruit at the last moment, then get frustrated by how difficult it is. This makes the research stressful and can hurt the quality of the research.

In this session, Jared will discuss how a well-planned and executed recruitment process can dramatically improve the value of the team’s overall UX work. Jared will directly connect how an investment in recruitment delivers the deep understanding about users that your entire team needs to design great products and services.

description:
User research is an ideal tool for improving the accuracy of our gut feelings.

Six stakeholder words that make UX leaders cringe: “I know what our users need.” There’s been no research, yet the stakeholder feels in their gut that they are right.

Here’s the thing: They might be. (Even a blind squirrel finds an acorn every so often.) Gut feeling is a thing and we need to learn to work with it.

In this discussion, Jared will explore how we work with confident stakeholders who don’t think we need to do research (or choose to ignore the research we’ve done). He’ll share how focusing on assessing and reporting confidence can improve the results when we need to rely on our gut for important decisions.

description:
A well-crafted roadmap journey delivers value to our users in every release.

When the product roadmap is a long wish list of features, it drives products and services to become overly complex and reduces their value. Yet, this approach to roadmaps is extremely common in many organizations.

Instead, if the team starts with a well-researched vision of what would solve the customers’ and users’ biggest challenges, they can build a roadmap on the steps necessary to achieve that vision. The resulting journey builds value every step of the way, avoiding complexity and allowing the team to focus on delivering great outcomes.

Join Jared in this lively discussion on how to shift your team from a cluttered wish list to a thoughtful, considered journey. He’ll discuss how great UX research changes the value of the roadmap, making it clear how every new release will achieve key outcomes and build value for customers.

description:
We don’t choose our design principles. The most effective principles choose us.

The best principles become powerful tools for making hard design decisions. At some point, we’ll be faced with a demanding choice between a quick win and a design alternative that will deliver a substantially improved experience for our users and customers. The best design principles will easily guide us to putting in the hard work and making the difficult decisions.

In this session, Jared will discuss how past difficult design decisions can show us the principles that reflect our values. He’ll walk us through a workshop exercise for identifying principles that’s both fun and effective.

description:
The (Not-So) Secret UX Strategy Session

As a UX Leader, does your work exhaust or energize you?

Not sure who needs to hear this… Life is both too short and too long to do work that exhausts you. 

During this session, Jared Spool will share the one thing that makes the difference in whether your UX work is exhausting or exciting. The one (not-so) secret thing is a proactive UX strategy.

If you’re finding your UX work to be exhausting, it’s likely your organization has a completely reactive UX strategy. A reactive UX strategy means your UX team just _reacts_ and scrambles to get work done as quickly as possible, compromising (big time) on quality and completeness. Then (without taking a break) picking up the next project, reacting to the work that needs to get done, and doing it again. It’s exhausting just thinking about it.

A proactive UX strategy puts planning and forethought into your UX work. Using a UX strategy, UX leaders get ahead of their work, influencing the most important design decisions in their organization before any real constraints are locked into place. _It’s what folks mean when they say UX should get “a seat at the table.”_

Stop being exhausted and discover how to become an energized UX leader. Craft and implement your organizations’ proactive UX strategy. 

  • Put together a multi-year vision of what it will be like to use your designs.

  • Conduct research that reveals how to deliver innovative products.

  • Deliver better-designed products and services that truly meet your users’ needs.

This free 1-hour session, led by Center Centre’s Jared, is for UX leaders ready to build a UX strategy that will transition to a proactive UX strategy. You’ll learn how you:

  • Craft and implement a proactive UX strategy in your organization.

  • Raise the value of UX with your executives and stakeholders.

  • Influence critical decisions and investments in good design, when it’s early enough in the project to have a broad impact.

Jared will show you how our Center Centre UX Strategy Leaders program has guided dozens of UX leaders to transform from reactive to proactive. He’ll show you the ins and outs of the program and how you can get the support you need to push your organization to take UX seriously.

Get everyone on the same page. Bring your team. Bring your boss. Learn what it takes to propel your organization to better UX.

Become energized. Become proactive. Drive UX strategically throughout your organization.

Come to this session to learn how to make it happen.

 

________________________________________

description:
MVPs: Good or Bad? (Hint: Usually Bad)

Monday, June 28 at 2pm ET (18.00 GMT)

Most MVPs are like runaway trains — ready to jump the tracks at any moment.


Minimum Viable Products, or MVPs as the kids like to call them, first showed up in 2001. However, it wasn’t until a decade later that it became an overnight sensation, especially with executive leaders who thought it was the answer to their biggest desire. 


It was the ultimate move-fast-and-break-things approach to delivering products quickly. (And, yup, it’s definitely a great way to break things quickly.)


In this discussion, Jared will show the range of how teams deliver MVPs today, including a few that might work well for your organization. Learn how to get MVPs back on track so they work to your organization’s advantage. Building things quickly doesn’t require that we ship something crappy to our customers.

description:
Telling Compelling User Stories

Monday, June 21 at 2pm ET (18.00 GMT)

Leadership happens for those who have the stories to tell about change and vision.


UX leaders lead through persuasion. They persuade through the stories they tell. Those stories emphasize the importance of change and the direction where things need to go. 


Every UX leader needs to tell compelling stories. And every UX leader can become a better storyteller.


In this session, Jared will guide us through the topic we don’t learn in design school: how to tell stories that compel change. He’ll share tips and techniques from some of the world’s best storytellers. You’ll see how small changes in how you tell your stories will make big changes in your power to persuade.

description:
Mapping Out Our Users’ Current Experiences

Monday, June 14 at 2pm ET (18.00 GMT)

Great designers don’t fall in love with their solutions. They fall in love with the problems.


Our user research highlights the challenges and opportunities with our users’ experiences, yet not everyone can participate in the research. There’s no better way to align on those challenges and opportunities than to show them in a map of our users’ current experiences. Great experience maps clearly illustrate to our executive stakeholders, key stakeholders, and peers where our users struggle and what makes great design valuable.


In this session, Jared will walk us through how UX leaders have used experience mapping to great advantage. We’ll see how those leaders increased the perceived value of UX, and directed efforts to improve the designs of their products and services.

description:
What UX Hiring Looks Like in a Post-Pandemic World

Monday, June 7 at 2pm ET (18.00 GMT)

How we build our teams is about to change one more time.

All indications suggest that the UX job market is about to explode. Organizations, large and small, profit and non-profit, have all discovered they need to deliver better online and offline experiences. The way people work, shop, attend school, travel, and live out their lives is undergoing massive change, and organizations will need teams that can address that change. UX professionals will be in more demand than ever, which means we’ll need to be far more strategic when we hire for our teams.

In this session, Jared will discuss how all this change will affect how we hire our future team members. He’ll show why the teams that get the earliest start — even before they’re ready to start interviewing — are the ones who will land the best applicants, the most qualified candidates, and quickly get their new team members on board.

description:
Why Do We Need a UX Strategy If We Already Have a Product Strategy?

Tuesday, June 1 at 2pm ET (18.00 GTM) 
(Note: this is a Tuesday session due to the Memorial Day holiday)

Why Do We Need a UX Strategy If We Already Have a Product Strategy? This question often comes up from product team leadership when they don’t understand how better UX can be strategic. They’ve created a product strategy that shows what goes into each product’s release into the future. 

Isn’t that enough? Not for the top organizations. They need more.

Adding a UX strategy to a product strategy is necessary to ensure the organization delivers products and services people want, need, and value. A great UX strategy shows how the organization itself needs to grow to deliver competitive, market-leading products.

In this session, Jared will discuss how product strategies and UX strategies come into fruition, and why they must work together. You’ll learn how the best UX leaders take advantage of their existing product strategy. You’ll see how you can achieve your organization’s goals by delivering well-designed products and services.

description:
There’s a belief that every business can be measured by some sort of core metric. Something that surfaces where an organization stands, relative to its peers. Business leaders have been sold on metrics, such as Net Promoter Score (NPS), System Usability Score (SUS), Customer Satisfaction (C-SAT), or Customer Effort Score (CES), as a holy grail of unified metric that shows how well things are going.

However, there’s a dirty secret that the consultants behind these scores won’t tell you: They don’t actually work. They aren’t helpful and, in many organizations, only make things worse.

In this live discussion, we’ll talk about what we can do about this. Do we try to convince execs that these numbers are flawed? Do we try to replace them with something else? The answer is neither. We’ll discuss what we might do instead.

description:
A dashboard is a common design deliverable. Its intention is to develop a display that immediately communicates a system’s health and helps users pinpoint where something may be out of whack.

While the intentions are good, the implementations are often lacking. Dashboards are often the result of incomplete research and users asking for something they don’t really want.

In this week’s live discussion, we’ll talk about why dashboards often don’t live up to their promise, and what we can do to truly help our users diagnose and treat systemic issues.

description:
Subject-Matter Experts (also known as SMEs) can be tremendously helpful in understanding what our users’ experiences are like. Because of their deep knowledge and experience in what it’s like to be one of our users, they’ve often been one themselves, they can contribute to our design understanding.

However, many teams treat SMEs as advocates for the users. The SMEs, with the best of intentions, often give out flawed advice and poor-informed requirements. This creates serious problems that go undetected until after the product or service ships.

In this week’s live discussion, we’ll talk about how your team can avoid these traps and get the most out of our Subject-Matter Experts.

description:
Getting to the heart of what makes a great user story.

In an Agile development process, teams build up—and then work through—their stockpile of user stories. Where do those user stories come from? In too many cases, they're either made up out from someone's imagination or are word-for-word customer feature requests. It's rare to see user stories we can tie directly back to user research.

In this live discussion, Jared will lead us on a journey, from UX outcomes, through experience visions and research-based scenarios, directly to well-crafted user stories. We'll see how starting from the right source helps us deliver innovative, better-designed products and services.

description:
Iteration is a core concept in Agile, yet do we know the most effective techniques?

Iteration is an essential part of any UX design process. We try out ideas, see how they work, then go back and try again. Ideally, we get better each time. However, we never really talk about how to iterate.

When we're intentional about what we want to learn and how we'll measure the results we achieved, we learn a whole lot more about our design. This makes us better designers and shows everyone we work with the value of great UX design.

In this live discussion, Jared will discuss the four phases of an iteration and how teams can get the most out of every phase. You'll explore how to integrate successful iterations into your Agile sprints to ensure your team delivers the best outcomes.

description:
Improve your Agile delivery by growing the UX capability of your team.

We can move fastest—and deliver better-designed products and services—when our teammates and stakeholders can make their own smart design decisions. So much of current UX practice is about compensating for a team that doesn't understand what a great experience could be. This gap in knowledge and understanding slows us down and makes work feel like a battle.

In this live discussion, Jared will talk through how teams introduce continuous learning as a driver to increase UX understanding and maturity. You'll explore techniques and methods for improving your Agile development process, freeing you up to work on the truly hard UX design challenges ahead of your team.

description:
A smart Design Ops approach dramatically increases your team's UX effectiveness.

When we’re successful at growing our organization's UX design effort, a design operations team (or design ops) becomes inevitable. Ast we grow, we'll also need a research operations team and content operations team. Operations teams are necessary to perform UX work at a large scale.

But when do we do this? Turns out, it’s not a function of the size of the team or a specific age of the UX efforts. Instead, it's when there are clear indications that the benefits of starting an operations team would pay off.

In this live discussion, Jared will describe the benefits and costs of starting an Ops team. He’ll explore what cues you should look for that tell you the timing is right to start one. You'll discuss what happens when you wait too long.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

What got us here isn’t going to get us there. Change starts with how we—and our key stakeholders—view how we design products and services. In this bonus session, Jared will share the common mindset shifts that empower stakeholders to embrace and promote our experience vision efforts. They’ll see UX in a new light, opening up possibilities for better design.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

What gets measured gets done. Once our experience vision is out there, we need to know how much progress the organization has made toward making it a reality. What are the essential UX metrics to complement our experience vision efforts? In this bonus session, Jared will map the _Persuasive UX Metrics_ framework directly to the work you did in last week’s intensive. Identify how you’ll know when you’ve succeeded at reaching your UX outcomes. You’ll learn to track the organization’s progress and identify the big obstacles that are your way. Good measures will make it easy for the organization to know exactly what’s left to do.

To join this discussion with Jared, click the link below and “Start” the Intensive program. Then, go to the Events section for event details and to RSVP.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

Every item in our product roadmap will either help us get closer to making our experience vision a reality, or it won’t. Since the roadmap dictates our product and service priorities, it’s critical we make sure we’ve prioritized those items that get us closer to the vision. Jared will show you the techniques for driving your product roadmap directly from your experience vision. Reframe features into the problems your team needs to solve, which, in turn, will make your products and services more competitive. This is where the changes truly pick up steam. 

To join this discussion with Jared, click the link below and “Start” the Intensive program. Then, go to the Events section for event details and to RSVP.

Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

Time to roll up our sleeves and start planning. We need to get our experience vision into the organization. Our experience vision needs to start telling the story of what great UX looks like. description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

This is the most important session of the week. If you don’t get executive support for your experience vision, it will die on the vine. You’ll know you’ve succeeded when your organization’s leadership is proudly telling your experience story to everyone they meet, explaining how this is everyone’s top priority. Jared will give you essential techniques for translating the benefits of your improved user experience into the priorities that propel stakeholders into action. You’ll learn to connect the dots between great UX and key business objectives. The executives will beg you to make your vision a reality. 


To join this discussion with Jared, click the link below and “Start” the Intensive program. Then, go to the Events section for event details and to RSVP.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness

Stories are what make us human. They are what motivate us to push for change. At the core of a great experience, a vision is a compelling story about how a better user experience will improve people’s lives. Jared will show you how you’ll use envisionments to tell the story of your experience vision. He’ll share some impressive examples of how other UX leaders have told their stories. You’ll leave ready to craft your own envisionments to tell your experience vision story. (Which is good, because that’s the homework for this session.) 


To join this discussion with Jared, click the link below and “Start” the Intensive program. Then, go to the Events section for event details and to RSVP.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness


Our experience vision is where we want our organization to end up. Yet our peers, stakeholders, and leadership will only understand its true value when they can see what today’s experience looks like. We need to surface the actual experience our current users face, so those in our organization can see the difference our experience vision will make. In this session, Jared will give you the tools you need to up your user research game. You’ll identify where there are critical gaps in your current research efforts that you’ll need to fill. You’ll learn how to best surface the experience to the stakeholders who will give your experience vision the most support.

To join this discussion with Jared, click the link below and “Start” the Intensive program. Then, go to the Events section for event details and to RSVP.

description:
Game-Changing Experience Visions | a Program in Leaders of Awesomeness


Experience Visions are an essential ingredient for driving our organization to deliver better-designed products and services. By telling a human-centered story of how our improved user experience will improve the lives of customers and users, we can get the entire organization bought into our mission. In our first session, Jared will show you how effective a great experience vision can be. You’ll see how UX leaders have driven innovation and great UX by telling compelling stories that motivate their entire organization. Bring the key stakeholders who’ll help you promote a great experience vision throughout your organization.
